title: Phase 0: Aspire Infrastructure Migration
description:
Convert the existing codebase to use .NET Aspire for service orchestration, telemetry, and local development experience. This enables polyglot service management, OpenTelemetry-based observability, and the Aspire Dashboard for debugging agent behavior.

## Why Aspire?
- Multi-agent orchestration with service discovery
- OpenTelemetry integration (industry standard, portable to production APM)
- Aspire Dashboard for real-time traces, logs, metrics visualization
- Future-proof for adding Redis, Postgres, message queues
- Better developer experience than Makefile-based orchestration

## Scope
- Add C# AppHost project (~30 lines) for orchestration
- Add OpenTelemetry SDK to Node.js backend
- Refactor ObservabilityService to emit OTEL spans
- Remove Makefile orchestration (replaced by Aspire)
- Requires .NET 10 SDK for Aspire 13 polyglot features

## What's Preserved
- All Drizzle schema and migrations
- All Zod models
- All repositories
- All business logic services
- Frontend components unchanged

title: Add AppHost C# project for Aspire orchestration
description:
Create the C# AppHost project that orchestrates the Node.js backend and React frontend using Aspire 13.

## Files to Create
```
AppHost/
├── AppHost.csproj
└── Program.cs
```

## AppHost.csproj
```xml
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">
  <PropertyGroup>
    <OutputType>Exe</OutputType>
    <TargetFramework>net10.0</TargetFramework>
    <IsAspireHost>true</IsAspireHost>
  </PropertyGroup>
  <ItemGroup>
    <PackageReference Include="Aspire.Hosting" Version="13.*" />
    <PackageReference Include="Aspire.Hosting.NodeJs" Version="13.*" />
  </ItemGroup>
</Project>
```

## Program.cs
```csharp
var builder = DistributedApplication.CreateBuilder(args);

var backend = builder.AddNodeApp("backend", "../backend", "dist/index.js")
    .WithHttpEndpoint(port: 3001, name: "api");

var frontend = builder.AddViteApp("frontend", "../frontend")
    .WithReference(backend);

builder.Build().Run();
```

## Prerequisites
- Install .NET 10 SDK
- Run `dotnet workload install aspire`

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] AppHost project builds successfully
- [ ] `dotnet run --project AppHost` starts both backend and frontend
- [ ] Aspire Dashboard accessible at http://localhost:15888

title: Update environment configuration for Aspire
description:
Update environment configuration to use Aspire-injected values instead of hardcoded defaults.

## Aspire Auto-Injected Variables
Aspire automatically injects these environment variables:
- `OTEL_SERVICE_NAME` - Service name for telemetry
- `OTEL_EXPORTER_OTLP_ENDPOINT` - OTLP collector endpoint
- `services__backend__api__0` - Backend URL for frontend

## Backend Changes (src/config.ts or equivalent)
```typescript
export const config = {
  port: parseInt(process.env.PORT || '3001'),
  host: process.env.HOST || '0.0.0.0',
  // Remove hardcoded OTEL config - use Aspire-injected values
  // OTEL SDK reads from env automatically
};
```

## Frontend Changes
Update API client to use injected backend URL:
```typescript
const API_BASE = import.meta.env.VITE_API_URL 
  || process.env.services__backend__api__0 
  || 'http://localhost:3001';
```

## Update AppHost to pass frontend env
```csharp
var frontend = builder.AddViteApp("frontend", "../frontend")
    .WithReference(backend)
    .WithEnvironment("VITE_API_URL", backend.GetEndpoint("api"));
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Backend reads OTEL config from environment
- [ ] Frontend connects to backend via Aspire service discovery
- [ ] No hardcoded localhost URLs remain
- [ ] Works in both Aspire-managed and standalone modes

description:

```json
{
  "scripts": {
    "dev": "tsx watch src/index.ts",
    "build": "tsc",
    "start": "node dist/index.js",
    "test": "vitest",
    "db:push": "drizzle-kit push",
    "db:studio": "drizzle-kit studio"

```

Frontend package.json:
```json
{
  "scripts": {
    "dev": "vite",
    "build": "vite build",
    "preview": "vite preview"
  }
}
```

## New Workflow
```bash
# Start everything with Aspire
dotnet run --project AppHost

# Individual service dev (if needed)
cd backend && npm run dev
cd frontend && npm run dev

# Database operations
cd backend && npm run db:push
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Makefile deleted

- [ ] README updated with new workflow

title: Test Aspire integration end-to-end
description:
Verify the complete Aspire integration works end-to-end.

## Test Scenarios

### 1. Service Startup
```bash
dotnet run --project AppHost
```
- [ ] Backend starts on port 3001
- [ ] Frontend starts on Vite dev server
- [ ] Aspire Dashboard accessible at http://localhost:15888

### 2. Aspire Dashboard Verification
- [ ] Both services appear in Resources view
- [ ] Service endpoints listed correctly
- [ ] Environment variables visible

### 3. Telemetry Flow

- [ ] Verify trace appears in Dashboard Traces view
- [ ] Check span attributes include service name

### 4. Custom Spans (Agent Operations)
- [ ] Trigger agent state change
- [ ] Verify custom span in Dashboard
- [ ] Check worker_id attribute present

### 5. Error Handling
- [ ] Trigger an error condition
- [ ] Verify error span has ERROR status
- [ ] Check error details in span attributes

### 6. Metrics
- [ ] Verify runtime metrics in Dashboard
- [ ] Check HTTP request metrics

### 7. Graceful Shutdown
- [ ] Stop Aspire (Ctrl+C)
- [ ] Verify clean shutdown (no orphan processes)
- [ ] Check final telemetry flushed

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] All test scenarios pass
- [ ] No console errors during operation
- [ ] Telemetry latency acceptable (<100ms)
- [ ] Memory usage stable over time

Create src/routes/work-items.routes.ts with REST endpoints: POST/GET/PATCH/DELETE /api/work-items, POST transition, POST assign.

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] POST /api/work-items returns 400 for invalid input

## Implementation Plan

notes:
## Implementation Summary

Created `backend/src/routes/work-items.routes.ts` with 8 REST endpoints using Fastify plugin pattern.

### Endpoints Implemented
- `POST /api/work-items` - Create (201, 400)
- `GET /api/work-items` - List with ?status/type filters (200)
- `GET /api/work-items/:id` - Get by ID (200, 404)
- `PATCH /api/work-items/:id` - Update (200, 404)
- `DELETE /api/work-items/:id` - Delete (204, 400, 404)
- `POST /api/work-items/:id/transition` - State machine (200, 400, 404, 409)
- `POST /api/work-items/:id/assign` - Agent assignment (200, 400, 404)
- `POST /api/work-items/:id/success-criteria` - Add criterion (200, 400, 404)

### Key Patterns Established
1. **Route Plugin Pattern**: Service injection via `WorkItemRoutesOptions`
2. **Validation**: Zod schemas with 400 error responses
3. **Error Handling**: Mapped service errors to HTTP status codes (404, 409)
4. **Testing**: Integration tests using `app.inject()` with in-memory SQLite

### Files Created/Modified
- `backend/src/routes/work-items.routes.ts` (8.5KB) - Route handlers
- `backend/src/routes/work-items.routes.test.ts` (17.9KB) - 30 tests
- `backend/src/app.ts` - Added DB injection & route registration
- `backend/src/index.ts` - Passes database to buildApp()

### Verification
- 610 tests passing
- TypeScript compiles
- All acceptance criteria met

title: Refactor to Vertical Slice Architecture
description:
Reorganize backend from layer-based architecture (routes/, services/, repositories/, models/) to feature-based vertical slices. Each feature should contain its own handlers, services, models, and tests in one place.

**Current Structure:**
- routes/ (10 files)
- services/ (27 files)
- repositories/ (14 files)
- models/ (5 files)

**Target Structure:**
- features/
  - agent-runtime/
    - agent-runtime.handler.ts
    - agent-runtime.service.ts
    - agent-runtime.repository.ts
    - agent-runtime.test.ts
  - work-items/
  - github-webhooks/
  - pull-requests/
  - concurrency/
  - repositories/
  - ...
- shared/ (cross-cutting: db, telemetry, config)

**Benefits:**
- Related code together - easier to understand features
- Easier to modify and delete features
- Better encapsulation and boundaries
- Reduced coupling between features
